answer_html: Hence \(\displaystyle x \equiv 2(7)x \equiv 2(4) \equiv 8 \mod{13}\) which completes the question.
answer_latex:
Hence
$\displaystyle x \equiv 2(7)x \equiv 2(4) \equiv 8 \mod{13}$ which
completes the question.
hints_html: We need to find the inverse of 7 modulo 13, possible since they are coprime. Use the Euclidean algorithm.
hints_latex:
We need to find the inverse of 7 modulo 13, possible since they are
coprime. Use the Euclidean algorithm.
hints_raw: We need to find the inverse of 7 modulo 13, possible since they are coprime. Use the Euclidean algorithm.
question: 1 (e)
sols_html:
Following the hint, we compute the inverse of 7 modulo 13. Then

\[\begin{aligned} 13 &= 7(1) + 6\\ 7 &= 6(1) + 1\end{aligned}\]

and back substituting gives \(\displaystyle 1 = 7 -6(1) = 7 - (13-7(1)) = 7(2) - 13\).

Thus, the inverse of 7 modulo 13 is 2. Hence \(\displaystyle x \equiv 2(7)x \equiv 2(4) \equiv 8 \mod{13}\) which completes the question.
sols_latex:
Following the hint, we compute the inverse of 7 modulo 13. Then

\begin{align*}
13 &= 7(1) + 6\\
7 &= 6(1) + 1
\end{align*}

and back substituting gives
$\displaystyle 1 = 7 -6(1) = 7 - (13-7(1)) = 7(2) - 13$.

Thus, the inverse of 7 modulo 13 is 2. Hence
$\displaystyle x \equiv 2(7)x \equiv 2(4) \equiv 8 \mod{13}$ which
completes the question.
sols_raw:
Following the hint, we compute the inverse of 7 modulo 13. Then

<math>
\begin{align}
13 &= 7(1) + 6\\
7 &= 6(1) + 1
\end{align}
</math>

and back substituting gives <math> \displaystyle 1 = 7 -6(1) = 7 - (13-7(1)) = 7(2) - 13</math>.

Thus, the inverse of 7 modulo 13 is 2. Hence <math> \displaystyle x \equiv 2(7)x \equiv 2(4) \equiv 8 \mod{13}</math> which completes the question.
